results.title: Lets make love = The Billionaire
results.creator_credit: George Cukor, Jerry Wald, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Artists
results.brief_description: Jean-Marc Clement (Yves Montand), bachelor, billionaire and womaniser, finds himself entrenched in the world of Broadway musicals when he is cast to play himself on Broadway. Discovering the news that he is to be satirised on stage, an outraged Clement heads to the theatre expecting a confrontation, but instead finds himself captivated by Amanda (Marilyn Monroe), one of the performers in the play, and despite his inability to sing, dance or act, accepts the offer of a role. Coached by some of the best in the business - Bing Crosby, Gene Kelly and Milton Berle, Clement sets out to make his mark on the stage as well as win the heart of the girl he loves without disclosing his true identity. Cast also includes Tony Randall (reprising his straight man role) as Clements PR agent. Includes the original theatrical trailer. Marilyn Monroe sings “My heart belongs to daddy”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Cukor, Jerry Wald, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Artists

results.title: Flaming star
results.creator_credit: Don Siegel, David Weisbart and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Considered one of Elvis Presley’s most dramatic roles, “Flaming Star” is a story about Pacer Burton’s (Presley) struggle as a young man torn between two cultures. Set some years after the Civil War, the small community that Pacer lives in finds itself under siege from the Kiowa tribe. After several settlers are killed the community turns on Pacer and his family and Pacer is forced to choose between the community he grew up in and his Native American roots. His choice leads to tragedy for both sides. “Flaming Star” enables Presley to showcase his acting ability without the usual musical intermissions. Cast also includes Dolores Del Rio, John McIntire and Barbara Eden. Features the original theatrical trailer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Siegel, David Weisbart and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation

results.title: Love me tender
results.creator_credit: Robert D Webb, David Weisbart and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Love Me Tender is most noteable for being Elvis Presley’s cinematic debut and the launching pad for one of his most recognisable hits Love Me Tender. The story of the Reno brothers starts at the end of the Civil War. Presley is Clint Reno a young farmer trying to keep the family farm running after the family are told that the oldest brother, Vance Reno has been killed in battle. Believing his brother is dead, Clint and Vance’s sweetheart Kathy marry. However, Vance returns with the intention of marrying Kathy. Clint receives reassurance from Vance that he bears no resentment towards the pair. However, the trios relationships with one another are soon tested when Vance is arrested and taken away for trial. This one event leads the trio to a climatic encounter that ends tragicly for all. While in the majority of the film Presley gets to display his acting ability the story is broken up with Presley singing and dancing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert D Webb, David Weisbart and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation

results.title: Mermaids
results.creator_credit: Richard Benjamin, Patrick Palmer, Wallis Nicita, Lauren Lloyd, Palmer and Nicita/Lloyd Productions
results.brief_description: Winona Ryder plays a strict Catholic schoolgirl growing up in the conservative early sixties and saddled with the grooviest and sexiest mother in town. A very funny romantic comedy, “Mermaids” celebrates the tensions, love and agonies of mother-daughter relationships. With Bob Hoskins and featuring an outstanding performance by Cher as the free-spirited mother of a very unconventional family. Based on the book by Patty Dann.

results.title: Love nest
results.creator_credit: Joseph Newman, Jules Buck and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: When serviceman Jim Scott (William Lundigan) returns home after 2 1/2 years in the Army he finds his wife, Connie (June Haver), has bought a run down apartment block and assumed the role of landlady at 337 Grammercy Place. Eager to resume his writing, he soon learns that the landlord is always home, and with a suspected Casanova swindler as a tenant, and a jealous wife following the arrival of Jim’s beautiful Army buddy WAC Bobby (Marilyn Monroe), it will take something exceptional to get his writing off the ground and save the decrepit building from being condemned. Cast also includes Frank Fay, Leatrice Joy and Jack Parr. Based on the novel by Scott Corbett. Includes the original theatrical trailer.

results.title: Limelight
results.creator_credit: Charles Chaplin and Celebrated Films Corporation
results.brief_description: The story of a washed-up music hall clown who regains confidence while helping a suicidal ballerina. This was Chaplin’s most personal film in turn nostalgic, melancholic and contemplative as he reflects on old age and the nature of art and comedy. There are only moments of humour (notably in tandem with Buster Keaton). Comedy is a tool for Chaplin’s larger enterprise of soul-searching and summing up. Cast also includes Claire Bloom and Nigel Bruce.

results.title: Modern times
results.brief_description: This was, in effect, the swansong of the Tramp in what is basically a ‘silent’ film which makes pointed use of synchronised speech at carefully selected moments. In a series of set pieces, in turn cynical and ironic, sentimental and nostalgic, Charlie unsuccessfully assumes a variety of occupations from assembly line worker to singing waiter. In between he becomes one of the unemployed, a willing prisoner and the companion of a working class girl. The film begins as social satire but Chaplin’s factory is too stylised to give the humor much bite. The film is ultimately more about homelessness than modernity. Chaplin’s political and philosophical naivete is disarming. His comic genius as a performer is timeless. Cast also includes Paulette Goddard and Chester Conklin.

results.title: Children of paradise = Les Enfants du paradis
results.creator_credit: Marcel Carne, Raymond Borderie and Societe Nouvelle Pathe Cinema
results.brief_description: The film begins with the titles superimposed on a theatre curtain which, when it lifts, ushers us into the chaotic world of the “boulevard of crime” in the mid-nineteenth century. Mime artist Baptiste (Jean-Louis Barrault) is desperately in love with the beautiful Garance (Arletty), but she is too world-weary and cynical to believe in his romantic notions of love; instead she begins an affair with the vain actor, Frederick, who dreams of leaving the pantomimes and performing Shakespeare in the grand theatres of Paris. This magical movie, consistently voted the best French film of all time, is a celebration of art and love. While behind the scenes the actors all battle with the bitter realities of unrequited desire or betrayed trust, on stage, performing to the “children of paradise” (those too poor to afford seats in the stalls and so have to sit in the “Gods”), they transform their sadness into the magic of dreams. It is as if, in this film, Marcel Carne makes good on all the promises of film and theatre to create a truly popular art, and he does so by celebrating not only the lives of the actors and performers on the “boulevard”, but also by celebrating the dreams and desires of the raucous, struggling audience that fills the “gods”. In the bond between performer and audience we see reflected the pleasures and mistakes of love itself. The sophisticated screenplay is by Jacques Prevert. Considered one of the cinema’s supreme works of art, the film was partly secretly filmed while Paris was still under Nazi occupation. On all levels, a labour of immense love. Cast also includes Maria Casares and Pierre Renoir. In French with English subtitles.
